articles.author: Maya Dhillon
articles.description:
Editor Jaimie Kaffash reflects on Pulse’s new sexism investigation to consider how the profession can tackle gender inequality There has been progress in redressing gender inequality in general practice. The very fact that 57% of GPs are female is testament to this. But even though women are the majority in the profession, there are still
The post The sexism particular to general practice appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: The sexism particular to general practice

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
A community health trust has won four more APMS GP contracts, bringing the total number of GP contracts under its control to ten. The East London Foundation Trust (ELFT) now provides GP care to 80,000 registered patients across north east London, Bedfordshire and Luton, with all but one of the practices under APMS contracts. The
The post Trust wins contracts for four more GP practices appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Trust wins contracts for four more GP practices

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
The first oral drug for preventing migraines where other treatments have failed should be available on the NHS, NICE has recommended in final draft guidance. Up to 170,000 people could be eligible for atogepant – also known as Aquipta – under the recommendations which cover both chronic and episodic migraines. It is expected that use
The post NICE recommends first oral drug for preventing both chronic and episodic migraines appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: NICE recommends first oral drug for preventing both chronic and episodic migraines

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
In the last part of our investigation on sexism in general practice, Anna Colivicchi looks at imbalances at leadership level  Female GPs still face sexist attitudes and harassment in the practice, hampered career progression and unequal pay. Yet in terms of representation in leadership positions, things do seem to be improving – although men still
The post Female GP leader numbers growing… but still work to do  appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Female GP leader numbers growing… but still work to do

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
The Scottish Government has suspended its ‘sustainability’ loan scheme for GPs due to oversubscription.  Last month, the Government wrote to practices to say it is ‘temporarily unable’ to process new loans and cannot confirm when the scheme will reopen.  Scottish health secretary Neil Gray blamed ‘significant’ reductions in UK Government funding for the suspension.  BMA
The post GPs lose access to ‘oversubscribed’ sustainability loan scheme appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GPs lose access to ‘oversubscribed’ sustainability loan scheme

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
The BMA is supporting a number of out-of-hours GPs across Wales who are being ‘deprived’ of employment rights such as holiday pay. Three OOH GPs recently ‘recouped’ a ‘significant sum’ of holiday pay in a ‘collective case’ at the employment tribunal, according to the BMA. GPs working in OOH services, which are in most cases
The post Employment tribunal sees out-of-hours GPs recoup holiday pay appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Employment tribunal sees out-of-hours GPs recoup holiday pay

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
Exclusive A number of recruitment agencies are telling practices not to ‘waste money’ on GP locums as physician associates ‘can work like a GP’. GPs have told Pulse there are concerns around ‘misleading’ wording used by some agencies that seem to be pushing for ARRS staff to replace GP locums. It comes after reports of
The post Practices told not to ‘waste money’ on ‘expensive’  GP locums appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Practices told not to ‘waste money’ on ‘expensive’  GP locums

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
The APMS contract for an 11,000-patient GP practice is set to be awarded to ‘super-practice’ provider Modality after the partners handed back their contract. A preliminary award notice, posted on Monday, named the Modality Partnership as the preferred bidder for the £18m contract. Last month, Nottingham and Nottinghamshire ICB (NNICB) announced that the Windmill Practice
The post Super-practice wins bid for GMS-turned-APMS contract appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Super-practice wins bid for GMS-turned-APMS contract

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
Demand for autism and ADHD assessments is increasing at such a rate that they have surpassed the ability of the NHS to keep up, the Nuffield Trust has warned. Rather than doing more of the same, a ‘radical rethink’ is needed of how services are provided to assess for neurodiversity, they concluded. The increase in
The post NHS has no hope of meeting autism and ADHD demand, warns report appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: NHS has no hope of meeting autism and ADHD demand, warns report

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
NHS England has set out what progress is expected on the GP recovery plan during 2024/25, including ensuring practices only divert patients to 111 in ‘exceptional circumstances’. Other key targets included reducing GP workload by further reducing bureaucracy; improving interface with hospitals; and increasing the number of patients who self-refer to specialist treatment. The GP
The post GP recovery plan update highlights 111 referral crackdown appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GP recovery plan update highlights 111 referral crackdown

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
Female GPs are statistically less well-paid than their male peers, and many say maternity pay isn’t adequate. Eliza Parr looks at how systemic sexism affects women in general practice. Read more from the investigation here It’s not easy to get to the root of cultural or everyday sexism. Female GPs may be suffering the emotional
The post The GP gender pay gap appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: The GP gender pay gap

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
GP trainers need to be paid more in order to achieve the planned expansion of training places, NHS England has said in its submission to the doctors’ pay review body. Last year, the NHS long-term workforce plan pledged to increase GP training places in England by 50% to 6,000 by 2031, but GPs expressed concerns
The post Pay GP trainers more to enable expansion, NHS England recommends appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Pay GP trainers more to enable expansion, NHS England recommends

articles.author: Maya Dhillon
articles.description:
Columnist Dr Copperfield puts forward his own unique clinical manifesto as an alternative to industrial action The next step to manning the barricades appears to be a manifesto developed after much talking and hand wringing culminating ‘potentially’ in something around November. Maybe, possibly, assuming you’re not busy and it doesn’t cause any inconvenience etc.  If all that
The post Replace industrial inaction with clinical strikes appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Replace industrial inaction with clinical strikes

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
NHS England has warned the Review Body on Doctors’ and Dentists’ Remuneration (DDRB) against recommending a GP pay increase above 2%. In its evidence to the pay review body, NHSE advised that any pay awards higher than the funding settlement from the Treasury will ‘put further pressure’ on the NHS budget. This could impact on
The post NHSE warns DDRB against recommending GP pay increase above 2% appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: NHSE warns DDRB against recommending GP pay increase above 2%

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
A GP has been ‘exonerated’ following a series of investigations spanning five years which related to a patient death.  The Medical Defence Union (MDU) said today that it had ‘successfully’ defended its GP member, who had faced a complaint, claim, NHS England investigation, and a GMC investigation.  Although the GMC investigation reached the stage of
The post GP ‘exonerated’ after five-year period of investigations into patient death appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GP ‘exonerated’ after five-year period of investigations into patient death

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
The ‘substitution’ of GPs with ‘non-doctors’ is resulting in more patients being sent to A&E, according to a former NHS England director. At a Sherwood Forest Hospitals’ board meeting last week, non-executive director Dr Aly Rashid said non-doctors cannot ‘distinguish between serious and less serious conditions’ meaning their ‘default position’ is to send patients to
The post Substituting GPs with ‘non-doctors’ increases A&E visits, says former NHSE director appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Substituting GPs with ‘non-doctors’ increases A&E visits, says former NHSE director

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
Presumptions around female GPs’ career intentions and interests continue to hamper progression. Eliza Parr reports. Read more from the investigation here It may seem that the overt sexism of the 20th century has long been resigned to the past. Like when Dr Susan Bowie interviewed to become only the second female GP the Shetland area
The post How sexism affects female GPs’ career progression appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: How sexism affects female GPs’ career progression

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
Exclusive A redundancy consultation placing a significant number of GPs at risk of unemployment could be in breach of regulations and ‘indirectly discriminatory’, the BMA has claimed. As revealed exclusively by Pulse last month, eMed – the new owner of GP at Hand – announced a large-scale redundancy process said to be affecting ‘mainly GPs’,
The post eMed GP redundancy consultation ‘likely to be unlawful’ and ‘discriminatory’, claims BMA appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: eMed GP redundancy consultation ‘likely to be unlawful’ and ‘discriminatory’, claims BMA

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
Practice pharmacists in Northern Ireland will be ‘more firmly established’ as the ‘clinical leads for medicines’ within general practice teams by 2030, a new government strategy has pledged. The Department of Health in Northern Ireland has published a strategy for the ‘future development’ of the general practice pharmacy sector after an evaluation of the service showed positive
The post Strategy pledges pharmacists as ‘medicine leaders’ in GP practices appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Strategy pledges pharmacists as ‘medicine leaders’ in GP practices

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
London has caught up with the West Midlands in the number of measles cases seen in the past month, the latest public health figures show. Since 4 March there have been 190 confirmed cases in England with 63 of them in London and 65 in the West Midlands, the UK Health Security Agency said in
The post Measles cases in London have caught up with West Midlands appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Measles cases in London have caught up with West Midlands

articles.author: Caroline Price
articles.description:
In this case-based CPD module, GP specialist in substance misuse Dr Alun George offers guidance on how to manage four scenarios involving prescription drugs associated with dependence or withdrawal symptoms Key points: The cases in this module are not based on real people and are for illustrative purposes only Case 1. A 36-year-old woman attends
The post Casebook: Prescription drug dependence appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Casebook: Prescription drug dependence

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
Female GPs are facing sexist comments, harassment and even abuse at work from patients and colleagues. In a major Pulse investigation, Eliza Parr looks at the scale of the problem Last year, a report by researchers and the Working Party on Sexual Misconduct in Surgery detailed harrowing allegations made by female surgeons. There were reports
The post The effect of sexual harassment and abuse on female GPs appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: The effect of sexual harassment and abuse on female GPs

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
The Government will make changes to the operation of the independent doctors’ pay review body, taking into account the views of the BMA, after reaching an agreement with consultants. The BMA’s consultants committee accepted the Government’s latest offer on pay and reform for the Review Body on Doctors’ and Dentists’ Remuneration (DDRB), putting an end
The post Government to change DDRB process as consultants call off strikes appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Government to change DDRB process as consultants call off strikes

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
GPs using artificial intelligence (AI) need to be aware of liability risks and maintain their ability to ‘critically appraise’ the technology, a digital health expert has warned. Speaking at the Pulse LIVE conference last week, Dr Annabelle Painter, an honorary digital health fellow at Imperial College and GP registrar, said GPs could be ‘the ones
The post GPs need to be ‘careful’ of liability risks when using AI, expert warns appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GPs need to be ‘careful’ of liability risks when using AI, expert warns

articles.description: Northern Ireland has moved all vasectomy services out of hospital and into general practice on a permanent basis - shifting around an extra £500m into primary care.
articles.title: Northern Ireland shifts all vasectomy services to general practice

articles.description: Draft guidance from NICE backs the first oral treatment for prevention of chronic and episodic migraines in a move that could benefit around 170,000 people in England.
articles.title: NICE backs first oral treatment to prevent chronic and episodic migraines

articles.description: The BMA has called for a government review to investigate why practices can’t afford to hire GPs, leaving thousands without enough work.
articles.title: BMA demands government review into GP unemployment crisis

articles.description: A practice that handed back its contract because of financial pressure is to be taken over by a 450,000-patient 'super-partnership' in a move GPs say reflects the direction of travel for general practice amid chronic underfunding.
articles.title: Super-partnership wins APMS deal in 'litmus test' for shift to large providers

articles.description: A GP practice has built Pharmacy First appointment slots into its daily rota to try to maximise the scheme's impact on practice workload.
articles.title: Practice builds Pharmacy First appointments into daily rota to maximise impact

articles.description: More than 14,000 doctors and dentists who opted out of the NHS pension scheme between 2015 and 2022 face a difficult choice over whether to reverse the decision, accountants have warned.
articles.title: GPs among thousands of doctors facing tough call on NHS pensions

articles.description: NHS England evidence that could shape recommendations on GP pay for 2024/25 is based on out-of-date information that does not reflect current financial pressures, accountants have warned.
articles.title: NHS evidence on GP pay 'completely out of date'

articles.description: BMA leaders have warned GP practices that physician associates (PAs) are 'not independent practitioners' and should be assessed individually to determine the safe scope of their role.
articles.title: Physician associates are 'not independent practitioners', BMA tells GP practices

articles.description: A GP practice in Bristol has sent a letter to its patients telling them of its 'struggle to stay afloat’ and warning it could close because of rising costs and underfunding.
articles.title: Practice sends letter to patients warning of 'struggle to stay afloat'

articles.description: The BMA has accepted the government's updated offer on pay for consultants in England, bringing an end to strikes by senior hospital doctors.
articles.title: Consultants accept updated pay offer bringing strikes to an end

articles.description: The GPonline team discusses the results of the BMA referendum on the GP contract and what happens next, and they look at whether general practice in England is shifting to a 'GP-lite' model as GPs struggle to find work.
articles.title: Podcast: GPs reject contract in referendum, plus is general practice moving to a ‘GP-lite’ model?

articles.description: Almost six in ten practices are considering cutting back on the services they offer patients in the coming year amid concerns about how they will cope with another below-inflation uplift to the GP contract, a GPonline poll suggests.
articles.title: Practices weigh up cutting services, staff and partner drawings in coming year

articles.description: More GMC complaints for 'minor concerns' that had no impact on patient care will be closed without an investigation, the regulator has said.
articles.title: GMC changes will mean fewer investigations for 'minor' complaints

articles.description: More than four in five GPs fear staff recruited through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) are replacing doctors in general practice.
articles.title: Four in five GPs fear ARRS staff are replacing doctors in general practice

articles.description: General practice in England is seeing the emergence of a 'worrying new model' with fewer GPs and a growing share of appointments delivered by other staff, doctors' leaders have said. But what's the evidence, and what impact is it having?
articles.title: Is general practice in England moving to a 'GP-lite' model?

articles.description: The network contract DES for 2024/25 says physician associates can see undifferentiated patients with approval from a GP supervisor, despite BMA guidance warning this is unsafe.
articles.title: Updated PCN contract at odds with BMA advice on physician associate role

articles.description: NHS England has closed its visa support service for GPs and practices in a move the RCGP fears could make it harder for thousands of newly qualified GPs to join the NHS workforce.
articles.title: NHS England scraps visa support service for GPs

articles.description: GPs have warned that practices are being 'overrun', after delivering 22% more appointments in February this year compared with the same month in 2019 - with 3% fewer GPs.
articles.title: 'Overrun' practices delivering millions more appointments with fewer GPs

articles.description: GPs have overwhelmingly rejected the 2024/25 GP contract for England and a GPonline poll suggests there is widespread support for industrial action in the coming year - but which forms of action would GPs back?
articles.title: Which forms of industrial action would GPs be prepared to take?

articles.description: Almost three-quarters of GPs are prepared to take industrial action in the coming year, a GPonline poll suggests.
articles.title: Three quarters of GPs prepared to take industrial action, poll suggests

articles.description: GPs' overwhelming rejection of the 2024/25 contract in a BMA referendum shows the profession is 'at boiling point' after being bullied and gaslit for years, England's GP committee chair has warned.
articles.title: General practice 'at boiling point' after years of bullying, BMA GP chair warns

articles.description: The global sum payments per weighted patient that practices receive will rise to £107.57 under the 2024/25 GP contract in England.
articles.title: GP core funding to rise by £2.84 per weighted patient in 2024/25

articles.description: Thousands of GPs have voted almost unanimously to reject the 2024/25 GP contract in a landmark referendum carried out by the BMA.
articles.title: GP referendum delivers overwhelming rejection of 2024/25 contract

articles.description: GP practices have been 'starved of resources' to the point where they can no longer afford to pay 'willing and skilled GPs' to work, the BMA chair has said in remarks linking underfunding to falling patient satisfaction.
articles.title: Practices 'unable to afford to pay willing and skilled GPs to work', warns BMA chair

articles.description: Dr Lucy Henshall and Penny Flack explain how their initiative Welcome Back To Work helps support GPs who have taken time away back into the workplace – and why we need a more flexible approach to GP retention at both a regional and national level.
articles.title: Podcast: Taking a different approach to GP retention

articles.description: An LMC has said that an in-depth report it produced on the financial crisis facing practices in its area has played a key role in the ICB rowing back on planned cuts to local GP funding this year.
articles.title: ICB halts possible GP funding cuts in wake of high-profile LMC report

sources.title: Public Health England - Activity on GOV.UK

articles.description: Guidance to support people who find it hard to attend cervical screening due to a mental health condition, previous traumatic experience or sexual and/or domestic abuse.
articles.title: Guidance: Cervical screening: support for people who find it hard to attend

articles.author: enquiries@nhsdigital.nhs.uk (NHS Digital)
articles.description:
In March 2024, the Westminster Health Forum policy conference on "Next steps for clinical research in the UK" brought together stakeholders from across the research industry. Heather Pinches shares her insights from the event.


I was delighted to be invited to represent NHS DigiTrials at the Westminster Health Forum policy conference. The event was chaired by The Rt Hon Baroness Neville-Jones DCMG, setting the stage for discussions on priorities for diversity, trust, transparency and public involvement in clinical trials.
articles.title: Putting people and partnership at the centre of clinical research

articles.author: enquiries@nhsdigital.nhs.uk (NHS Digital)
articles.description:
Chiara Garattini and Kate Burn explain how working in our Data and Analytics sub-directorate has challenged the assumptions of our user-centred design team.


A big part of early work on projects typically involves helping our colleagues to focus a bit less on the characteristics of their products and the requirements of their internal processes, and to instead start by involving users to understand their needs.


Therefore, it's been interesting to work on projects that required our team to get deep into the weeds of the process in order to, ultimately, put the focus back on users.
articles.title: We had to follow the data, not our users

articles.author: enquiries@nhsdigital.nhs.uk (NHS Digital)
articles.description:
Thasmim Ali describes the changes we’ve made to our digital service catalogue to make it easier for our stakeholders to find out and understand what national digital services are available for NHS staff and organisations to use.


NHS England provides more than 100 national digital services for the NHS. They’re listed in the service catalogue on the NHS England Digital website.


However, after speaking with digital leaders across the system, our ‘Who Does What’ programme team identified two important problems.
articles.title: How we’re transforming our digital service catalogue

articles.author: enquiries@nhsdigital.nhs.uk (NHS Digital)
articles.description:
Thasmim Ali describes the changes we’ve made to our digital service catalogue to make it easier for our stakeholders to find out and understand what national digital services are available for NHS staff and organisations to use.


NHS England provides more than 100 national digital services for the NHS. They’re listed in the service catalogue on the NHS England Digital website.


However, after speaking with digital leaders across the system, our ‘Who Does What’ programme team identified two important problems.
articles.title: How we’re transforming our digital service catalogue

articles.author: enquiries@nhsdigital.nhs.uk (NHS Digital)
articles.description:
Most prescriptions are still paper-based in secondary care. Business analyst Andy Harrison describes the technical groundwork we’ve laid to allow these settings to go digital.


The little green FP10 paper prescriptions have all but disappeared in primary care. 18 years ago, we launched the Electronic Prescription Service (EPS) and it has since become an indispensable tool for primary care teams. Nearly all GP practices use it and about 95% of primary care prescriptions are now sent electronically. Last year, that amounted to 1 billion items dispensed using the service. It’s a safer, faster and more convenient way to prescribe.
articles.title: How we’re modernising electronic prescribing

articles.author: enquiries@nhsdigital.nhs.uk (NHS Digital)
articles.description:
In March 2024, the Westminster Health Forum policy conference on "Next steps for clinical research in the UK" brought together stakeholders from across the research industry. Heather Pinches shares her insights from the event.


I was delighted to be invited to represent NHS DigiTrials at the Westminster Health Forum policy conference. The event was chaired by The Rt Hon Baroness Neville-Jones DCMG, setting the stage for discussions on priorities for diversity, trust, transparency and public involvement in clinical trials.
articles.title: Putting people and partnership at the centre of clinical research

articles.author: enquiries@nhsdigital.nhs.uk (NHS Digital)
articles.description:
Reproducible analytical pipelines (RAP) help ensure all published statistics meet the highest standards of transparency and reproducibility. Sam Hollings and Alistair Bullward share their insights on adopting RAP and give advice to those starting out.


Reproducible analytical pipelines (RAP) are automated statistical and analytical processes that apply to data analysis. It’s a key part of national strategy and widely used in the civil service.
articles.title: Why we’re getting our data teams to RAP

articles.author: enquiries@nhsdigital.nhs.uk (NHS Digital)
articles.description:
User researcher Fern Williams describes how we created a new paper patient registration form to complement the online ‘Register with a GP surgery’ service, allowing everyone to have a consistent user experience and leaving no one digitally excluded.


One of the guiding principles of the ‘Register with a GP surgery’ service is to be accessible and inclusive to all. Though there is a shift towards digital to make registering with a GP surgery easier and more convenient for both patients and practice staff, we haven’t forgotten the importance of developing a paper registration form for those who prefer not to or can’t use a digital service.
articles.title: How do you put a digital service on paper?

articles.author: enquiries@nhsdigital.nhs.uk (NHS Digital)
articles.description:
Chiara Garattini and Kate Burn explain how working in our Data and Analytics sub-directorate has challenged the assumptions of our user-centred design team.


A big part of early work on projects typically involves helping our colleagues to focus a bit less on the characteristics of their products and the requirements of their internal processes, and to instead start by involving users to understand their needs.


Therefore, it's been interesting to work on projects that required our team to get deep into the weeds of the process in order to, ultimately, put the focus back on users.
articles.title: We had to follow the data, not our users

articles.author: kbradshaw
articles.description: An expansion of same day emergency care services across the country has seen thousands more people every week get the rapid tests and treatment they need to avoid an overnight stay in hospital – with the total up by more than a tenth in just a year. New data shows there has been an 11% […]
articles.title: NHS rollout of same day emergency care allows hundreds of thousands to return home quicker

articles.author: jboshell
articles.description: An NHS spokesperson said: “NHS England is very grateful to Dr Cass and her team for their comprehensive work on this important review over the past four years. “The NHS has made significant progress towards establishing a fundamentally different gender service for children and young people – in line with earlier advice by Dr Cass […]
articles.title: NHS England responds to the publication of the independent review of gender identity services for children and young people

articles.author: jboshell
articles.description: Hundreds of thousands more people a month will have the option to refer themselves for key services such as help with incontinence, podiatry, or hearing tests without needing to see a GP, as part of the NHS primary care access recovery plan. Around 180,000 more people a month will be able to self-refer for additional […]
articles.title: NHS self-referral for tests and appointments for hundreds of thousands of patients

articles.author: nowen
articles.description: Thousands of people unknowingly living with hepatitis C are to be identified, diagnosed and cured thanks to major NHS investment in rapid testing technology and an extension of a ground-breaking medicines deal. New liver scanning and portable testing units will be deployed in a range of communities where patients are at high risk of contracting the infection. […]
articles.title: NHS expands ‘one-hour’ liver testing to help detect and eliminate Hep C

articles.author: kbradshaw
articles.description: Commenting on the final weekly sitrep for this winter, Professor Julian Redhead, NHS England’s National Clinical Director for Urgent and Emergency Care, said: “Today’s figures highlight just how hard staff across the NHS have worked this winter in the face of significant demand and ongoing industrial action, with more than 1.7 million people taken to hospitals by […]
articles.title: NHSE comment on latest weekly winter sitrep figures

articles.author: kbradshaw
articles.description: New operational figures published today show the success of the NHS MMR catch-up campaign, with tens of thousands more vaccinations delivered in the first three months of this year compared to the same period in 2023. The most significant increase in vaccinations was for those aged five to 25 years old, with four times as […]
articles.title: NHS MMR catch up campaign successfully boosts uptake

articles.author: kbradshaw
articles.description: The NHS has appointed Dr Sue Mann, a consultant and lead for women’s health in City and Hackney, North East London, as its first ever national clinical director for women’s health In her new role, Dr Mann will help implement the Women’s Health Strategy alongside supporting the roll out of women’s health hubs across England. […]
articles.title: NHS announces first ever national clinical director for women’s health

articles.author: kbradshaw
articles.description: Tens of thousands of children and adults living with type 1 diabetes across England are set to receive an ‘artificial pancreas’ in a world-first initiative being rolled out by the NHS. The groundbreaking device continually monitors a person’s blood glucose, then automatically adjusts the amount of insulin given to them through a pump. Local NHS […]
articles.title: NHS rolls out artificial pancreas in world first move

articles.author: kbradshaw
articles.description: The NHS is stepping up a national campaign to recruit former members of the Armed Forces who want to join the health service and offer their valuable skills to caring for patients. Running until March 2025, the new NHS Long Term Workforce Plan drive will encourage serving and retired armed forces personnel and their families […]
articles.title: NHS launches innovative new drive to recruit armed forces veterans

articles.author: kbradshaw
articles.description: More patients will be able to get through to their GP surgery for an appointment, thanks to upgraded phone technology rolled out across the country.   Almost every GP practice in England has upgraded their phone systems – a key part of the GP access recovery plan.   More than 5,800 GP practices use a digital system for […]
articles.title: Boosted GP practice access for patients thanks to new phone technology

articles.author: kbradshaw
articles.description: Almost one hundred thousand cancer patients have now benefitted from early access to the latest and most innovative treatments, thanks to the NHS Cancer Drugs Fund. The NHS is set to hit a major milestone in April with 100,000 cancer patients benefitting from faster access to more than 100 drugs (in over 250 indications) through the […]
articles.title: 100,000 patients receive early access to latest cancer therapies on NHS

articles.author: kbradshaw
articles.description: More than 2.7 million people have already used a new prescription feature in the NHS App since its launch two months ago. The convenient new feature, which was launched in January, allows patients in England to see when their prescriptions have been issued and view their prescribed medication. Since the launch, there have been 18.4 […]
articles.title: More than 2.7 million use new NHS App feature for prescriptions in first two months

articles.author: kbradshaw
articles.description: NHS England will launch a new attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) taskforce alongside government to improve care for people living with the condition.  The new taskforce will bring together expertise from across a broad range of sectors, including the NHS, education and justice, to better understand the challenges affecting those with ADHD and help provide a joined up approach in response to concerns […]
articles.title: NHS to launch cross-sector ADHD taskforce to boost care for patients in England

articles.description: According to WHO's 2024 Global Hepatitis Report, the number of lives lost due to viral hepatitis is increasing. The disease is the second leading infectious cause of death globally, the same as tuberculosis, a top infectious killer.
articles.title: WHO sounds alarm on viral hepatitis infections claiming 3500 lives each day

articles.description:
A WHO-led multi-agency mission accessed Al-Shifa Hospital in north Gaza on 5 April to conduct a preliminary assessment of the extent of destruction and identify needs to guide future efforts to restore the facility. The highly complex mission was conducted in close partnership with the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), United Nations Mine Action Service (UNMAS), United Nations Department for Safety and Security (UNDSS), and in collaboration with the acting Hospital Director.
Prior to the mission, WHO’s efforts to reach the hospital to medically evacuate patients and staff and conduct an assessment were denied, delayed or impeded 6 times between 25 March and 1 April.
Like the majority of the north, Al-Shifa Hospital ­– once the largest and most impor…
articles.title: Six months of war leave Al-Shifa hospital in ruins, WHO mission reports

articles.description:
To mark World Health Day (7 April), the World Health Organization (WHO) is running the “My health, my right” campaign to champion the right to health of everyone, everywhere. 
The campaign advocates for ensuring universal access to quality health services, education, and information, as well as safe drinking water, clean air, good nutrition, quality housing, decent working and environmental conditions, and freedom from discrimination. 
All around the world, the core challenges consistently compromising the right to health are political inaction coupled with a lack of accountability and funding, compounded by intolerance, discrimination and stigma. Populations facing marginalization or vulnerability suffer the most, such as people who live in poverty, are displaced, are older or live with d…
articles.title: WHO calls for action to uphold right to health amidst inaction, injustice and crises

articles.description: The arrival of rapid diagnostic test (RDT) kits for cholera in Malawi today signals the start of a global programme that will see more than 1.2 million tests distributed to 14 countries at high risk for cholera over the next several months. Countries that will receive kits in the coming weeks in this largest-ever global deployment include those currently severely impacted by cholera outbreaks, such as Ethiopia, Somalia, Syria, and Zambia. This programme will improve the timeliness and accuracy of outbreak detection and response by boosting routine surveillance and testing capacity and helping rapidly identify probable cholera cases. Critically, it will also help countries monitor trends and build an evidence base for future preventive programmes, supporting the achievement of national cholera control and elimination targets.
articles.title: Global deployment of rapid diagnostic tests to boost fight against cholera

articles.description: Ahead of World Health Day, focused on ‘My Health, My Right’, the World Health Organization (WHO) announces the launch of S.A.R.A.H., a digital health promoter prototype with enhanced empathetic response powered by generative artificial intelligence (AI).
articles.title: WHO unveils a digital health promoter harnessing generative AI for public health

articles.description:
WHO Member States agreed to resume negotiations aimed at finalizing a pandemic agreement during 29 April to 10 May. The decision came at today’s end of two weeks of intensive country-led discussions on critical subjects aimed at making all countries of the world better prepared for, and able to effectively and equitably respond to, future pandemics.

This ninth meeting of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Body (INB9) started on 18 March and ended today. Government negotiators discussed all articles from the draft agreement, including adequate financing for pandemic preparedness, equitable access to medical countermeasures needed during pandemics and health workforce strengthening. 

“Our Member States are fully aware of how important the pandemic agreement is for protecting future generati…
articles.title: WHO Member States agree to resume negotiations aimed at finalizing the world’s first pandemic agreement

articles.description:
WHO has launched a new network for coronaviruses, CoViNet, to facilitate and coordinate global expertise and capacities for early and accurate detection, monitoring and assessment of SARS-CoV-2, MERS-CoV and novel coronaviruses of public health importance. 
CoViNet expands on the WHO COVID-19 reference laboratory network established during the early days of the pandemic.  Initially, the lab network was focused on SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, but will now address a broader range of coronaviruses, including MERS-CoV and potential new coronaviruses. CoViNet is a network of global laboratories with expertise in human, animal and environmental coronavirus surveillance.
The network currently includes 36 laboratories from 21 countries in all 6 WHO regions. 
Representatives of the l…
articles.title: WHO launches CoViNet: a global network for coronaviruses

articles.description: Older women and women with disabilities face particular risk of abuse, yet their situation is largely hidden in most global and national violence-related data, according to two new publications released today by the World Health Organization (WHO).
articles.title: WHO calls for greater attention to violence against women with disabilities and older women

articles.description: The Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) and WHO today signed a new memorandum of understanding, reaffirming the critical role that parliamentarians play in enabling good health to foster stable and equitable societies.
articles.title: Working together for a healthier, safer world: WHO and IPU renew partnership

articles.description: A high-powered intervention by 23 former national Presidents, 22 former Prime Ministers, a former UN General Secretary and 3 Nobel Laureates is being made today to press for an urgent agreement from international negotiators on a Pandemic Accord, under the Constitution of the World Health Organizaion, to bolster the world’s collective preparedness and response to future pandemics.
articles.title: Call for urgent agreement on international deal to prepare for and prevent future pandemics

articles.description: Immediate action is needed to stem an unprecedented multi-year upsurge in cholera cases worldwide, according to the International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision. Actions include investing in access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene, testing and detecting outbreaks quickly, improving quality of and access to healthcare, and fast-tracking additional production of affordable oral cholera vaccine (OCV) doses to better prevent cases.
articles.title: Millions at risk from cholera due to lack of clean water, soap and toilets, and shortage of cholera vaccine

articles.description:
The latest analysis from the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) partnership released today warns that the situation in Gaza is catastrophic, with northern Gaza facing imminent famine and the rest of the Strip at risk as well. 
"The IPC announcement reflects the dire situation that the people of Gaza are facing," said WHO Director-General Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus. "Before this crisis, there was enough food in Gaza to feed the population. Malnutrition was a rare occurrence. Now, people are dying, and many more are sick. Over a million people are expected to face catastrophic hunger unless significantly more food is allowed to enter Gaza." 

Before the recent months’ hostilities, 0.8% of children under 5 years of age were acutely malnourished. Today’s report shows that a…
articles.title: Famine in Gaza is imminent, with immediate and long-term health consequences

articles.description: Ahead of World Tuberculosis (TB) Day, which is marked on 24 March, WHO has released an investment case for TB screening and preventive treatment. A modelling study developed with Governments of four countries - Brazil, Georgia, Kenya and South Africa - highlights the impact to be achieved from expanding TB screening and preventive treatment.
articles.title: WHO urges investments for the scale up of tuberculosis screening and preventive treatment

articles.description:
A major new study released by The Lancet Neurology shows that, in 2021, more than 3 billion people worldwide were living with a neurological condition. The World Health Organization (WHO) contributed to the analysis of the Global Burden of Disease, Injuries, and Risk Factor Study (GBD) 2021 data. 
Neurological conditions are now the leading cause of ill health and disability worldwide. The overall amount of disability, illness and premature death (known as disability-adjusted life years, DALYs) caused by neurological conditions has increased by 18% since 1990.
Over 80% of neurological deaths and health loss occur in low- and middle-income countries, and access to treatment varies widely: high-income countries have up to 70 times more neurological professionals per 100 000 people than low- …
articles.title: Over 1 in 3 people affected by neurological conditions, the leading cause of illness and disability worldwide

articles.author: Bill Toulas
articles.description: Approximately 16,500 Ivanti Connect Secure and Poly Secure gateways exposed on the internet are likely vulnerable to a remote code execution (RCE) flaw the vendor addressed earlier this week. [...]
articles.title: New Ivanti RCE flaw may impact 16,000 exposed VPN gateways

articles.author: Sergiu Gatlan
articles.description: Microsoft has fixed a known issue causing 0x80073cf2 errors when using the System Preparation (Sysprep) tool after installing November Windows 10 updates. [...]
articles.title: Microsoft fixes Windows Sysprep issue behind 0x80073cf2 errors

articles.author: Bill Toulas
articles.description: Hackers are using Facebook advertisements and hijacked pages to promote fake Artificial Intelligence services, such as MidJourney, OpenAI's SORA and ChatGPT-5, and DALL-E, to infect unsuspecting users with password-stealing malware. [...]
articles.title: Fake Facebook MidJourney AI page promoted malware to 1.2 million people

articles.author: Andrea Chipman
articles.description: Today's briefing includes the launch of the Innovation Directory for Wales and the expansion of same-day emergency care services across England.
articles.title: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing ☕

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: A new artificial intelligence tool developed by King's College London has shown promising results in predicting patient's health trajectories.
articles.title: King’s College London AI tool to predict health events

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Upgraded phone technology has been rolled out across the country, enabling more patients to get through to their GP surgery for an appointment.
articles.title: Upgraded phone technology for GP practices rolled out across England

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: A total of £1.1m has been awarded to Bedfordshire, Luton and Milton Keynes ICS enabling it to provide digital solutions to local residents.
articles.title: Bedfordshire, Luton and Milton Keynes ICS £1m award for digital solutions

articles.author: Andrea Chipman
articles.description: Today's briefing includes the NHS introducing self-referral for a number of key services and Bayer and Google collaborating on AI solutions for radiology.
articles.title: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing ☕

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde's emergency department clinicians are now using an AI tool from Qure.ai to help improve decision making.
articles.title: NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde first to roll out head-CT AI solution

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: Two new solutions using the power of artificial intelligence to enhance research into dementia and cognitive decline are being worked on by NTT DATA.
articles.title: NTT DATA enhances dementia research with artificial intelligence

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: This briefing features North West Anglia NHS FT replacing two LIMS with Clinisys Winpath and Asda offering online pharmacy home delivery.
articles.title: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing ☕

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Rapid Health’s Smart Triage is helping NHS GP practices and Primary Care Networks solve the '8am rush' issue, CEO and co-founder Carmelo Insalaco explains.
articles.title: Smart Triage shines and sets Rapid Health apart from competitors

articles.author: Andrea Chipman
articles.description: Patients who fail to take medicines as prescribed are costly to health systems and risk seeing their own conditions worsen.
articles.title: HealthNet Homecare platform looks to predict medication non-adherence

articles.author: Andrea Chipman
articles.description: Patients who fail to take medicines as prescribed are costly to health systems and risk seeing their own conditions worsen.
articles.title: HeathNet Homecare platform looks to predict medication non-adherence

articles.author: Andrea Chipman
articles.description: Labour has announced a new partnership with Virgin Media O2, to ensure every child with type 1 diabetes can benefit from the latest technology.
articles.title: Labour to partner with Virgin Media to expand access to diabetes tech

articles.author: Andrea Chipman
articles.description: Today's briefing includes Canon installing its Aquilion One CT system at the Royal Bournmouth and NHSE extending rapid testing for Hepatitis C.
articles.title: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing ☕

articles.author: Andrea Chipman
articles.description: North Health Tees and Hartlepool NHS Trust, and InterSystems, has implemented a digitalised ward admissions process that focuses on empowering nurses.
articles.title: North Tees improves nurse admissions process with TrakCare

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: An e-rostering platform from Patchwork Health is helping to streamline operations at North Cumbria Integrated Care NHS Foundation Trust.
articles.title: North Cumbria introduces Patchwork Health e-rostering

articles.author: Andrea Chipman
articles.description: Today's briefing covers a US start-up developing  AI mammograms that can help diagnose heart disease in women and WHO's launch of an AI health promoter.
articles.title: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing ☕

articles.author: Andrea Chipman
articles.description: OMRON Healthcare today announced the acquisition of Luscii Healthtech, a fast-growing scale-up in the field of remote consultation service platforms.
articles.title: OMRON acquires Luscii Healthtech to advance remote patient monitoring

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Our latest roundup features a new CEO at West London NHS Trust and NHS England’s AI and digital workforce national clinical lead departing.
articles.title: Movers and shakers news roundup

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: This briefing includes ANS supporting the charity Facial Palsy UK by implementing Microsoft's Copilot service and a study around lethal heart rhythms.
articles.title: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing ☕

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: A new report from The Digital Coalition has has highlighted some of the limitations that users of the NHS App experience.
articles.title: Digital Coalition report highlights limitations of NHS App

articles.author: Cora Lydon
articles.description: SilverCloud by Amwell now fully supports digital therapy in the NHS Talking Therapies, helping support patients with mental health issues.
articles.title: SilverCloud now fully supports digital therapy in NHS Talking Therapies

sources.title: Have I Been Pwned latest breaches

articles.description: In April 2024, nearly 6 million records of Salvadoran citizens were published to a popular hacking forum. The data included names, dates of birth, phone numbers, physical addresses and nearly 1M unique email addresses. Further, over 5M corresponding profile photos were also included in the breach.
articles.title: Salvadoran Citizens - 946,989 breached accounts

articles.description: In March 2024, the independent fan forum Kaspersky Club suffered a data breach. The incident exposed 56k unique email addresses alongside usernames, IP addresses and passwords stored as either MD5 or bcrypt hashes.
articles.title: Kaspersky Club - 55,971 breached accounts

articles.description: In March 2024, the Indian audio and wearables brand boAt suffered a data breach that exposed 7.5M customer records. The data included physical and email address, names and phone numbers, all of which were subsequently published to a popular clear web hacking forum.
articles.title: boAt - 7,528,985 breached accounts

articles.description: In February 2024, the paid survey website SurveyLama suffered a data breach that exposed 4.4M customer email addresses. The incident also exposed names, physical and IP addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth and passwords stored as either salted SHA-1, bcrypt or argon2 hashes. When contacted about the incident, SurveyLama advised that they had already "notified the users by email".
articles.title: SurveyLama - 4,426,879 breached accounts

articles.description: In March 2024, 1.3M unique email addresses from the online store for purchasing goods from China, Pandabuy, were posted to a popular hacking forum. The data also included IP and physical addresses, names, phone numbers and order enquiries. The breach was alleged to be attributed to "Sanggiero" and "IntelBroker".
articles.title: Pandabuy - 1,348,407 breached accounts

articles.description: In June 2023, the Tacoma-Pierce County Health Department announced a data breach of their Washington State Food Worker Card online training system. The breach was published to a popular hacking forum the year before and dated back to a 2018 database backup. Included in the data were 1.6M unique email addresses along with names, post codes, dates of birth and approximately 9.5k driver's licence numbers.
articles.title: Washington State Food Worker Card - 1,594,305 breached accounts

articles.description: In March 2024, English Cricket's icoachcricket website suffered a data breach that exposed over 40k records. The data included email addresses and passwords stored as either bcrypt hashes, salted MD5 hashes or both. The data was provided to HIBP by a source who requested it be attributed to "IntelBroker".
articles.title: England Cricket - 43,299 breached accounts

articles.description: In July 2022, the direct download website Exvagos suffered a data breach that was later redistributed as part of a larger corpus of data. The breach exposed 2.1M unique email addresses along with IP addresses, usernames, dates of birth and MD5 password hashes.
articles.title: Exvagos - 2,121,789 breached accounts

articles.description: In August 2016, breached data from the vBulletin forum for GSM-Hosting appeared for sale alongside dozens of other hacked services. The breach impacted 2.6M users of the service and included email and IP addresses, usernames and salted MD5 password hashes.
articles.title: GSM Hosting - 2,607,440 breached accounts

articles.description: In January 2019, the now defunct MMO and RPG game SwordFantasy suffered a data breach that exposed 2.7M unique email addresses. Other impacted data included username, IP address and salted MD5 password hashes.
articles.title: SwordFantasy - 2,690,657 breached accounts

articles.description: In March 2024, millions of rows of data from the New Zealand media company MediaWorks was publicly posted to a popular hacking forum. The incident exposed 163k unique email addresses provided by visitors who filled out online competitions and included names, physical addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, genders and the responses to questions in the competition. Some victims of the breach subsequently received ransom demands requesting payment to have their data deleted.
articles.title: MediaWorks - 162,710 breached accounts

articles.description: In March 2024, tens of millions of records allegedly breached from AT&T were posted to a popular hacking forum. Dating back to August 2021, the data was originally posted for sale before later being freely released. At the time, AT&T maintained that there had not been a breach of their systems and that the data originated from elsewhere. 12 days later, AT&T acknowledged that data fields specific to them were in the breach and that it was not yet known whether the breach occurred at their end or that of a vendor. AT&T also proceeded to reset customer account passcodes, an indicator that there was sufficient belief passcodes had been compromised. The incident exposed names, email and physical addresses, dates of birth, phone numbers and US social security numbers.
articles.title: AT&T - 49,102,176 breached accounts

articles.description: In September 2022, the online photo sharing platform ClickASnap suffered a data breach. The incident exposed almost 3.3M personal records including email addresses, usernames and passwords stored as SHA-512 hashes. Further, a collection of paid subscriptions were also included and contained names, physical addresses and amounts paid.
articles.title: ClickASnap - 3,262,980 breached accounts
